results.title: MTV Video Music Awards: 7 Memorable Moments
results.abstract: Taylor Swift set a record and Chappell Roan, Sabrina Carpenter and Katy Perry delivered noteworthy performances as the show struck a balance between past and present.
results.byline: By Shivani Gonzalez, Jon Pareles and Ross Scarano

multimedia.caption: Katy Perry performed a medley of her hits before accepting MTV’s Video Vanguard Award.
Katy Perry performed a medley of her hits before accepting MTV’s Video Vanguard Award.

results.title: The Song That Connects Jackson Browne, Nico and Margot Tenenbaum
results.abstract: Browne wrote “These Days” at 16. Now 75, he and some famous admirers reflect on his unexpected mainstay: “If a song is worth anything, it’s about the life of the listener.”

multimedia.caption: Jackson Browne in Laurel Canyon, 1967. He started writing one of his signature songs, “These Days,” three years prior.
Jackson Browne in Laurel Canyon, 1967. He started writing one of his signature songs, “These Days,” three years prior.
Jackson Browne in Laurel Canyon, 1967. He started writing one of his signature songs, “These Days,” three years prior.

results.title: Hollywood Is Heading for Broadway (and Off). Here’s a Cheat Sheet.
results.abstract: George Clooney as Murrow! Denzel Washington as Othello! Mia Farrow as a larcenous landlord! So much to see!

results.title: Michael Kiwanuka Makes the Simple Profound. The World Is Listening.
results.abstract: The English songwriter will follow up his Mercury Prize-winning 2019 LP with his fourth album, “Small Changes,” in November.

results.title: Is Robert Frank’s Late Work Worth Viewing?
results.abstract: MoMA’s centenary exhibition of the photographer revered for a groundbreaking book makes the case for what came after — but was often left in the shade.

multimedia.caption: “New York City, 7 Bleecker Street,” a self-portrait of the artist, in September 1993. Frank caught himself studying a strip of filmed images.

results.title: ‘Speak No Evil’ Review: He Seemed So Nice

results.title: A Double Homage for James Baldwin’s 100th. Will It Ever Be Enough?
results.abstract: At the New York Public Library, two exhibitions add little to a very public writer’s mystique. But our critic dived deeper.

results.title: They Said Her Music Was Too Exotic. Now She’s a Classical Star.
results.abstract: Gabriela Ortiz, Carnegie Hall’s composer in residence this season, has spent her career channeling the sounds and sensibilities of Latin America.

multimedia.caption: Gabriela Ortiz, photographed at her home in Coyoacán. “There is no quiet place in Mexico City,” she said. “Everyone has something to say. And music is how we say it.”
multimedia.copyright: Jackie Russo for The New York Times

results.title: How a Survival Shooter Built in Ukraine Evolved as a War Rages On
results.abstract: The Ukrainian developers of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 are trying to distance the video game from Russia’s invasion, but the conflict inevitably altered the creative process.

multimedia.caption: “We see things differently now, though the prism of war,” said Yaroslav Kravchenko, the game’s story director.
“We see things differently now, though the prism of war,” said Yaroslav Kravchenko, the game’s story director.
“We see things differently now, though the prism of war,” said Yaroslav Kravchenko, the game’s story director.

results.title: ‘Before I Let Go’ and 5 More Essential Frankie Beverly and Maze Songs
results.abstract: The singer, who died on Tuesday at 77, had a smooth, sunny delivery that turned at least one track into a lasting anthem of Black celebrations.

results.title: Kit Connor and Rachel Zegler Are Star Crossed in Central Park
results.abstract: As the stars of the “Romeo + Juliet” that opens on Broadway, they will die for love. And to make that convincing, they need to become friends first.

multimedia.caption: “I can joke with you, which is nice,” Zegler said to Connor. “If I can’t joke with you, how are we going to fall in love every night to the point that makes us suicidal?”
multimedia.copyright: Scott Rossi for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Chaos’ Reigns!
results.abstract: ‘Chaos’ is an unruly word for a volatile time. The election is the least of it.

results.title: Charles Biasiny-Rivera, Champion of Latino Photography, Dies at 93
results.abstract: A New Yorker of Puerto Rican descent, he helped start a collective that brought recognition to Hispanic photographers and illuminated life in the city’s barrios.

multimedia.caption: Charles Biasiny-Rivera in 2020. He helped found En Foco, a photographers’ collective that is, one critic wrote, “devoted to documenting Latino life from the inside.”
Charles Biasiny-Rivera in 2020. He helped found En Foco, a photographers’ collective that is, one critic wrote, “devoted to documenting Latino life from the inside.”

results.title: No Shoes, No Phones Allowed at This Brooklyn Shop
results.abstract: Plus: Sardinian furniture, a Jordan Casteel exhibition and more recommendations from T Magazine.

results.title: Robert Caro Reflects on ‘The Power Broker’ and Its Legacy at 50
results.abstract: Caro’s book on Robert Moses, a city planner who reshaped New York, is also a reflection on “the dangers of unchecked power,” and remains more resonant and relevant than ever.

results.title: ‘The Power Broker’ Is Finally Getting a Digital Edition. What Took So Long?
results.abstract: Robert Caro’s mammoth study of the urban planner Robert Moses is coming out as an e-book this month, on the 50th anniversary of the biography’s publication.
des_facet: The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York (Book)

multimedia.caption: Robert Caro had long opposed a publishing “The Power Broker as an e-book. But, he said, he recently “realized more and more people will do their reading on electronic books, so you want those generations to learn about it also.”

Robert Caro had long opposed a publishing “The Power Broker as an e-book. But, he said, he recently “realized more and more people will do their reading on electronic books, so you want those generations to learn about it also.”

results.abstract: Swim with sea lions, cycle along the coast, and gorge on ceviche and fried-fish sandwiches in Peru’s underappreciated capital.

results.title: Jimmy Kimmel Chides Trump for His Debate Performance
results.abstract: “More than 67 million Americans watched the debate on television last night, and of that 67 million, the only one who seems to think Trump did a good job is Donald Trump,” Kimmel said.

multimedia.caption: “I woke up, I ate a big cat for breakfast, then I had a baby, then I had an abortion right after that, and then I went to pick up my kids from their mandatory transgender surgery operations after school,” Jimmy Kimmel joked of his “liberal elite day.”

results.title: Art Museum Fires 3 Employees for Wearing Kaffiyehs
results.abstract: The Noguchi Museum said the headscarves, a symbol of Palestinian identity, violated a dress code that recently banned “political messages, slogans or symbols.”

results.title: Danity Kane Singer Sues Sean Combs, Alleging Threats and Groping

results.title: Frankie Beverly, Frontman of the Soul Group Maze, Is Dead at 77
results.abstract: A consistent hitmaker on the R&B charts for almost 50 years, he had announced just this year that he would be retiring.
results.byline: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Richard Sandomir

multimedia.caption: Frankie Beverly in performance in 2012. He led his group, Maze, to success on the R&B charts and Black radio, but the group never had a lot of crossover pop success.
